conclusion: To determine if the displacements of cars A and B are the same, analyze the area under their respective velocity-time graphs.
The vertical axis represents velocity (v) and the horizontal axis represents time (t). Curves A and B represent the velocities of Car A and Car B, respectively.
Displacement is the integral of velocity with respect to time, corresponding to the area under the velocity-time graph.
For Car A, the area under the curve from t=0 to t=t1 is bounded by curve A, the time axis, and vertical lines at t=0 and t=t1.
For Car B, the area under the curve from t=0 to t=t1 is bounded by curve B, the time axis, and vertical lines at t=0 and t=t1.
Visually, the area under curve A appears larger than the area under curve B.
Curve A starts at a higher initial velocity v2 and decreases to a final velocity higher than the initial velocity of Car B.
Curve B starts at a lower initial velocity v1 and decreases to a final velocity lower than the final velocity of Car A.
Since the area under curve A is greater than under curve B, the displacement of Car A is greater than Car B during this time interval.
No, the displacements of cars A and B are not the same. Car A has a greater displacement than Car B.
